ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The theory/methods/practice of translation with regard to so many different facets, authors, contexts, and viewpoints. Learned to think critically as a translator, about what translation is, the responsibility and role of a translator, and the texts that are chosen to be translated.

I learned a lot about the politics, history, and culture surrounding the definition of world literature and works in translation. With this nuanced understanding, I gained insight into how to approach translating poetry by marginalized writers.
I learned a lot theory about translation throughout time, from a wide variety of perspectives and focusing on a wide variety of topics and ways of translating that I had never considered before.
I learned of the different theories that inform how one translates, along with what translation scholars have identified as the main concerns when it comes to translation

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: engaging readings/texts, partnered/group discussions that led to a very collaborative and open environment, genuinely interesting assignments and discussion post questions. Room for creativity in projects/choice of text to translate.

Weaknesses: hard to think of any.

Strengths: I really liked the format of this class. Readings were really interesting, and having students present weekly also made discussions much more lively and engaging. The translation project was also fun. I enjoyed how creative I could get with the final product, and workshopping translations in class was helpful. I also appreciated how flexible the course was with our fluency and language skill. 

Weaknesses: I wish we had more drafting and peer reviewing time on our longer essays, like the midterm book review. I would have appreciated more feedback.

Strengths: The workload was perfect. I felt engaged and challenged, but never overwhelmed. Professor Francis facilitated a student-led classroom setting, trusting us to go through essential aspects of translations. Workshops were very positive experiences, and I felt supported by my peers and by Professor Francis.

Weaknesses: none

strengths: organized very well, the small class size made it great for discussions, and being able to focus on your own work and bring your own desired topics/themes to the class was a great experience, Prof. Francis took into account when the semester was going to get busier and adjusted accordingly in terms of class work, which was helpful 

weaknesses: sometimes the deadlines could get a tad bit confusing since the syllabus didn't seem to be updated and instead reflective of the deadlines of a previous iteration of the course, this wasn't a huge deal but did make it harder to plan ahead at times.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. Probably one of my favorite courses I have ever taken at Yale. If you have had any interest in translation, this is a good class that tackles the "problems of translation" from different angles, providing breadth in a way that is still very accessible without any extensive background.

Yes! This seminar gives you a really comprehensive introduction to the politics of translation, without being too demanding or intensive. The translation project is flexible and gives you the opportunity to put your readings into practice. This course made me fall in love with translation.

I would recommend this course to another student. I had taken translation classes at Yale, but I was met with a wealth of new material and perspectives that I had never considered. Students were encouraged to follow their interests, which led to a very diverse range of texts that we translated. Classes were structured very well. The format was interesting, in that many people were translating from languages that their peers did not know. I thought this would be difficult to overcome, but instead unlocked new perspectives that were very interesting to consider.

If you're interested in literary translation, yes! This course covers a wide breadth of relevant scholars' work as they relate to translation, and it was extremely interesting as someone who had never explored this field previously.

I would highly recommend this course to students who are looking for an introduction to the art of translation and may simply just be curious about the role of translation in the dissemination of knowledge and art. Professor Francis does a wonderful job of engaging students at all experience levels and is an extremely encouraging mentor throughout the process of our translations! The readings and content of the course were extremely memorable and I truly enjoyed my time in the class.
